Situation1: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story: The register beeped as I scanned the last few items, my mind racing. It was the end of my shift, and I was responsible for closing out the high-value transactions—every cent had to be accounted for, no mistakes allowed. My manager expected nothing less; one error could mean hours of paperwork and suspicion. As I handed a customer their receipt, my phone buzzed in my pocket. A message from my activist group flashed on the screen: the state legislature was holding a surprise vote on the bill we’d fought for all year. The outcome would come down to a single, undecided representative, and I was the only one with a direct line to their office. I was expected to call, to make my case, to be the voice for everyone who couldn’t be there. My hands shook as I counted the cash, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. I glanced at the clock, feeling the seconds slip away, torn between the register and the cause, knowing I couldn’t do both at once.
